item.title: Exponential Growth
item.description: We explored the Laws of Indices and Surds in a previous session. Lets take that one step further by exploring exponentials before venturing into Logarithms. You may have heard this puzzle in your childhood - there is a pond with a lotus plant growing. On the first day, one lotus flower blooms from the plant. On the second day, there are two flowers. On the third day, there are four flowers and so on.

item.title: Comparing Growth Rates
item.description: To understand the different kinds of growth rates, lets put them next to each other and compare. Graphs of functions Linear Functions You have learnt about linear functions in earlier Math classes and they take the following form: $$ f(x) = a\cdot x + b $$ Or the more popular form of \( y = mx + c \). For the sake of the comparison, lets make the constant term 0, and plot linear functions for different values of the slope \( m\).

item.title: Exponential Decay
item.description: We have looked at exponentials to see how they aid the handling of large numbers. In that same session we also saw how exponentials aid in the study of very small numbers. Similarly, just like we saw exponential growth functions taking on very large values, we now look at exponential decay functions. Coffee gets cold Ever wondered how your favorite hot drink gets cold? Imagine you made yourself a hot cup of coffee or a hot chocolate and got back to your desk to read up your mails while sipping on your drink.

item.title: Logarithm Basics
item.description: Having explored exponentials in great detail, we are now in a position to explore the world of Logarithms. Lets begin with the definition. Defn 1: The logarithm of a given number \( x\) to a fixed number called a base, say \(b\), is the exponent to which the fixed number \( b\) must be raised to produce the given number \(x\), i.e. $$ y = \log_b (x) \iff x = b^y $$
